title: Living longer but not healthier: Study finds this country has biggest gap between lifespan and 'healthspan' - Hindustan Times
summary:
Living Longer but Not Healthier: Study Finds This Country Has Biggest Gap Between Lifespan and 'Healthspan'

Date: Dec 18, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

New research shows that while humans are living longer, this does not equate to living healthier lives. The study, which analyzed data from 183 countries, highlights a widening gap between lifespan and healthspan, with the US having the largest gap.

  • The average American will live 12.4 years with disability or illness.
  • Globally, lifespan increased from 79.2 to 80.7 years for women and from 74.1 to 76.3 years for men between 2000 and 2019.
  • The gap between lifespan and healthspan increased to an average of 9.6 years, a 13% rise since 2000.
  • The US has the greatest gap, reporting chronic disease as a significant issue due to mental health and substance abuse.
“The data show that gains in longevity are not matched with equivalent advances in healthy longevity” - Dr. Andre Terzic

This study emphasizes the necessity of addressing the healthspan-lifespan gap to improve the quality of life in older age.
newTitle: Living Longer but Not Healthier: Study Reveals Gap Between Lifespan and Healthspan

title: India sets up its first diabetes biobank in Chennai: Know its importance and why it matters - India TV News
summary:
India Establishes First Diabetes Biobank in Chennai

Published on: December 12, 2024 Source: India TV News

The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and Madras Diabetes Research Foundation (MDRF) have created the country's first diabetes biobank in Chennai to facilitate research and improve treatment for diabetes, a growing health concern.

  • The biobank aims to conduct high-tech research to identify causes of diabetes.
  • It will help recognize diabetes at an early stage and discover new biomarkers for treatment.
  • The initiative will position India as a key player in the global fight against diabetes.
  • The first study of the biobank involved over 1.2 lakh individuals and highlighted the diabetes epidemic affecting over 10 crore people in India.
  • Type 1 and type 2 diabetes have been found increasingly prevalent among the youth, necessitating the biobank's contributions.
“The biobank will help in identifying diabetes at an early stage and identifying new biomarkers to improve treatment.” - Dr. V Mohan, MDRF President

The establishment of the diabetes biobank in Chennai marks a significant step towards combating diabetes in India and could lead to breakthroughs in treatment and management of the disease.
newTitle: India Establishes First Diabetes Biobank in Chennai

The truth behind popular health foods: What you need to know - The Indian Express
summary:
The Truth Behind Popular Health Foods: What You Need to Know

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Indian Express

This article explores the misconceptions surrounding popular health foods and their actual nutritional benefits, emphasizing moderation and informed choices.

  • Foods labeled as "diet" or "low-calorie" can still have high calorie content.
  • Dark chocolate has health benefits but should be consumed in moderation.
  • Grilling lean meats can create harmful substances; it's healthier to consume them in soups.
  • Homemade curd is a better choice than low-fat yoghurts that may contain added sugars.
  • Artificial sweeteners can cause digestive issues and may be harmful if overconsumed.
  • A balanced diet should emphasize variety and moderation.
“A healthy diet relies on moderation, and a range of food options is necessary to satisfy nutritional requirements.”

In conclusion, understanding the true nutritional value of popular health foods is essential to making healthier dietary choices.
newTitle: The Truth Behind Popular Health Foods: What You Need to Know

An Occasional Treat Could Be Better For Your Heart Than No Added Sugar at All - ScienceAlert
summary:
An Occasional Treat Could Be Better For Your Heart Than No Added Sugar at All

Publication Date: December 9, 2024 | Source: Frontiers in Public Health

This study from Lund University reveals that consuming sweet treats occasionally may lower the risk of cardiovascular disease compared to a strict 'zero-sugar' diet.

  • Those enjoying occasional pastries or chocolate have a reduced risk of heart disease.
  • Different sources of added sugar have varying impacts on cardiovascular health.
  • The researchers analyzed data from 69,705 individuals aged 45 to 83.
  • Liquid sugars may lead to overconsumption due to lower satiety compared to solid foods.
  • Future research could investigate the relationship between sugar, heart disease, and obesity.
“While our observational study cannot establish causation, these findings suggest that extremely low sugar intake may not be necessary or beneficial for cardiovascular health.” - Suzanne Janzi

In conclusion, occasional sweet treats might not only be enjoyable but could also contribute positively to heart health, as opposed to rigidly avoiding sugar.
newTitle: An Occasional Treat Could Be Better For Your Heart Than No Added Sugar at All

12 ways how doing yoga in winter can improve your health - Health shots
summary:
12 Ways Yoga in Winter Can Improve Your Health

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Healthshots

This article discusses the various health benefits of practicing yoga during the winter months, addressing common ailments like stiffness, low energy, and joint pain.

  • Yoga helps keep your body warm by generating heat through movement and stretching.
  • Practicing yoga boosts immunity, helping to fend off winter illnesses like colds and flu.
  • Yoga enhances energy levels, combating seasonal lethargy and fatigue.
  • It improves cardiovascular health by reducing blood pressure and enhancing circulation.
  • Regular yoga practice combats stiffness, improving flexibility and range of motion.
  • Yoga relieves joint pain and reduces inflammation during cold weather.
  • Mindful breathing and meditation techniques in yoga help manage stress and improve mood.
  • Yoga strengthens lungs and enhances respiratory health.
  • It alleviates back pain and promotes better posture.
  • Yoga promotes a healthy sleep cycle, countering the effects of shorter days.
  • It aids in weight management by encouraging mindful eating habits.
  • Yoga improves digestion, reducing the risk of constipation common in winter.
“Practicing yoga helps improve blood circulation and release endorphins, which are natural mood and energy boosters.”

In conclusion, embracing yoga during winter not only combats seasonal challenges but also promotes overall physical and mental well-being.
newTitle: 12 Ways Yoga in Winter Can Improve Your Health

title: What is Dinga Dinga? The disease spreading in Uganda - The Economic Times
summary:
What is Dinga Dinga? The disease spreading in Uganda

Publication Date: Recent
Source: Local Media

A disease called 'Dinga Dinga,' translating to 'shaking like dancing,' is on the rise in Uganda, particularly affecting women and girls in the Bundibugyo district. The condition results in uncontrollable body shaking and significant mobility challenges.

Key Points:

  • Dinga Dinga primarily affects women and girls.
  • Symptoms include excessive body shaking, fever, extreme weakness, and difficulty in walking.
  • Around 300 cases have been documented, with no reported casualties.
  • The disease may be treated with antibiotics, and health officials report a high recovery rate.
  • Dr. Kiyita Christopher advises against herbal medicines without scientific backing.
  • Public health campaigns are educating residents about symptoms and treatment.
“I felt weak and got paralyzed, with my body shaking uncontrollably whenever I tried to walk. It was very disturbing.” - Patience Katusiime

The situation is under investigation by health officials, and there are ongoing efforts to find the cause and educate the public on prevention measures.
newTitle: Understanding Dinga Dinga: The Mysterious Disease in Uganda

title: Yoga trends 2024: Desk yoga to eco-friendly practices, know the trends that ruled this year - Hindustan Times
summary:
Yoga Trends 2024: Desk Yoga to Eco-Friendly Practices

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

In 2024, yoga has become more essential in the fast-paced world, focusing on mental health with new trends emerging that cater to modern needs.

  • Desk Yoga: Quick routines for office workers to reduce stress.
  • Face Yoga: Popular for toning facial muscles and promoting youth.
  • Aqua Yoga: Low-impact practice enhancing balance in water.
  • Aerial Yoga: Combines yoga with aerial hammocks for improved strength.
  • Outdoor and Adventure Yoga: Unique experiences like paddleboard and mountain yoga.
  • Digital Yoga Experiences: Smart online classes with VR and AR interactions.
  • Wellness-Focused Approaches: Mental health integration into yoga practice.
  • Targeted Yoga Classes: Specialized classes for unique health needs.
  • Eco-Friendly Practices: Focus on sustainable yoga gear and health.
  • Technology in Yoga: Wearables that enhance practice analysis.
  • Making Yoga for Everyone: Adaptive programs for all abilities.
  • Cultural Understanding: Emphasis on yoga's rich cultural roots.
  • Ongoing Transformation: Yoga evolves with society's health perspectives.
“From digital platforms to mindful practices, yoga in 2024 shows how movement, technology, and well-being can work together.” - Himalayan Siddhaa Akshar

These trends indicate a shift toward a more integrated understanding of health and wellness in yoga, making it relevant in contemporary life.
newTitle: Yoga Trends 2024: Innovations from Desk Yoga to Eco-Friendly Practices

title: Six reasons to start chewing guava leaves every day - The Indian Express
summary:
Six Reasons to Start Chewing Guava Leaves Every Day

Publication Date: October 2023   Source: Indian Express

Guava leaves are a nutritious powerhouse, known for their antioxidants, vitamins, and anti-inflammatory properties. They have traditionally been used for health benefits and are gaining popularity as a natural remedy.

Key Points:

  • Rich source of vitamins, especially vitamin C and B, beneficial to immune and cognitive health.
  • Contains important minerals like calcium, potassium, magnesium, and iron for bone and cardiovascular health.
  • Antioxidants like quercetin help mitigate oxidative stress and inflammation.
  • Daily consumption aids digestion, balances blood glucose, strengthens the immune system, lowers bad cholesterol, reduces cancer risk, and alleviates menstrual cramps.
“Chewing guava leaves daily can provide numerous health benefits due to their rich nutrient profile.” - Kanikka Malhotra, Consultant Dietician

Integrating guava leaves into your diet can enhance overall well-being, but moderation is key.
newTitle: Six Reasons to Start Chewing Guava Leaves Every Day

title: Men With History of Cannabis Use Have Less Cognitive Decline From Early Adulthood to Late Midlife - Pharmacy Times
summary:
Men With History of Cannabis Use Have Less Cognitive Decline From Early Adulthood to Late Midlife

Publication Date: 2024; Source: Brain and Behavior

This study investigates the relationship between cannabis use and cognitive decline among a male population, finding that those with a history of cannabis use exhibit less cognitive decline as they age compared to nonusers.

  • The study utilized data from the Danish Aging and Cognition (DanACo) cohort involving 5162 men.
  • Findings suggest cannabis users experienced less cognitive decline, averaging 1.3 to 1.5 IQ points less than nonusers.
  • Approximately 39.3% of participants reported using cannabis at least once.
  • No significant relationship was found between the age of initiation of cannabis use and cognitive decline.
  • The study's limitations include a low participation rate (14.3%), which may affect the generalizability of the results.
"Cannabis users had a slightly higher average IQ at conscription, while nonusers experienced a mean cognitive decline of about 6.8 IQ points."

The study provides insight into the long-term effects of cannabis use on cognitive decline, highlighting the need for further research, especially among diverse populations.
newTitle: Men With History of Cannabis Use Experience Less Cognitive Decline in Midlife
